ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i learned how to speak Vietnamese in a more fluid and coherent manner
I deepened my understanding of the Vietnamese language and grew my Vietnamese vocabulary.

Improved my Vietnamese speaking, writing, reading, and comprehension. I really appreciated the Viet American history unit, helped me connect to my family more. The final project this semester was a family oral history video and it was a great learning experience for me.
I learned a lot of new vietnamese vocabulary and a lot about Vietnamese culture!
I improved my reading and writing skills in Vietnamese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Thay Quang really cares about the wellbeing of his students and is very accommodating. I was very engaged throughout the course and learned a lot.
Strengths: The class is extremely chill, and I've truly learned a lot. By nature of the course, I grew very close with my classmates, and the atmosphere was very collaborative.
There was a lot of work, but I think it was all very helpful.

This course was extremely poorly organized and did not even have a syllabus. The professor would assign random assignments at will and by mouth so it was difficult to recall and keep up with the assignments. It was not specified whether or not the assignments were graded. We had to submit everything through email (which the professor did not mention) because the professor did not upload on CANVAS. We mostly had to figure things out by ourselves as a class. Assignments depended on if the majority of the class did the work. The assignments would always be so tedious and you would need to dedicate so much time to it so the work would overshadow the rest of your classes. The Vietnamese we were learning was not colloquial and would not be used in normal conversation; the words we were learning was ancient which the professor expected us to know.

Strengths: Great professor that really cares about student success. Topics covered helps to grow knowledge of Vietnamese culture.

Weaknesses: Class ends after one semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! If you want to learn Vietnamese and are proficient, this is a great course
I would recommend this course to a student looking to learn Vietnamese or meet students who are equally as passionate about Vietnamese culture.
Totally. This class will improve your Viet, help you emphathize with your family/Viet people, and it is a great classroom community.
I would if the student really wants to improve their Vietnamese!
I would not recommend this course to another student.

Yes! A bit more work than L3 viet, but we go into much deeper topics during this semester that I really enjoyed learning and think are important to learn (such as topics like refugees). The deadlines for work is quicker and there's more work, but it's definitely very doable still!
Yes. Please take this class if you want to learn Vietnamese. I now feel so much more comfortable talking to my parents / family members.
